div1.head: Report: Impounded Waters, by Joseph Augustine LePrince, [1921?]
div1.p:
I M P O U N D E D W A T E R S
_________
by JA LePrince

The impounding of waters in river valleys is an essential
part of the proper development of the natural resources of
the state and is of marked benefit to its present and future
citizens. It is believed such improvements can be accomplish-
ed at a reasonable cost without rendering unhealthful consider-
able areas adjacent to such projects.

As previous development of water power in states in the
malaria belt has given many well-known illustrations where
such procedure (in this state as well as others) resulted in
a rapid and pronounced increase of malaria fever, in some in-
stances of a more pernicious type than formerly obtained, it
became necessary for the State Board of Health to investigate
such outbreaks and make scientific investigations of the re-
lation of newly impounded water to the increase and prevalence
of malaria in territory adjacent.

Among other facts that developed were the following, which
have also been found to hold true in general in other southern
states where malaria prevails:

(1). When large bodies of water are impounded it takes
several years or more for nature to bring the newly formed pond
under such control conditions as are biologically found in old
lakes or ponds whether natural or artificial (man made).

(2). Whether the conditions brought about by the impound-
ing of waters produce a situation favoring marked increase of
(2)
malaria conveying mosquitoes or not depends on:
(a) The details of topography affected.
(b) Shape of contour of the lakes boundary line.

(c) The character and presence of trees, brush, and
vegetation, especially that near or adjacent to and above
and below its high and low water flow lines.
(d) Exposure of the lake surface to wind action.

(e) Frequency of strong wind in all inlets of the lake
in summer and in autumn seasons.
(f) Prevalence of heavy storms.

(g) Character of aquatic and semi-acquatic growth in
the rain shed of the lake.

(h) Amounts of floatage and debris carried by the river
feeding the lake.

(i) Pronounced fluctuation of water level, may be (or by
proper control can frequently be made to be) a controlling fac-
tor. - Say two to four feet at ten day intervals or less in the
mosquito season - the 24 inch for more abrupt and the 48 inch
for affecting flat slopes.

(j) Natural fluctuations of water level, seasonal, summer,
weekly or daily.

(k) Quantity and distribution of natural enemies of mos-
quito larvae.
(l) Other important factors.

(3) Under normal conditions in nature many aquatic
insects have aquatic enemies that prey on them to the extent of
seriously decreasing their numbers. The mosquito, in its early
stage of development is exclusively aquatic and is preyed upon
by various insects and certain species of fish. Some species
of fish not only destroy very few larvae, but they sometimes
(3)
almost eliminate the mosquito destroying kind of fish. They
also may limit the scope of action of those minnows which pre-
fer mosquito larvae to other food and insects. When water is
freshly impounded, the ratio of (fish that prefer Anopheles
mosquito larvae to other food) to the mosquito larvae supply
is often very low or below what will probably be true several
years or more later. This has been observed to be the general
rule in the upper portions of arms and indentations or long
bights of lakes. Also if no precautionary measures (or un-
satisfactory precautionary measures) are undertaken, there
will generally be very much more protection afforded to the
mosquito larvae during the early years of the life of the
artificial pond than is commonly found in older ponds or lakes
whether natural or man made, and consequently their natural
enemies will have difficulty in reaching them.

(4) The particular places in newly formed lakes or ponds
where Anopheles larvae frequently are to be found in relatively
large numbers are:

(a) In floatage and collections of floatage. This
is often composed of leaves, pine needles, small sticks,
branches of trees, logs, pieces of bark, etc., and some of it
is sometimes covered with green algae. Anopheles larvae are
also often found in quantity among collections of aquatic or
semi-aquatic plants, especially so if certain algae are present.

(b) Larvae are often found clinging to isolated
pieces of bark or other drift when against or close to abrupt
banks in deep water when wind and wave action are or have been
absent or light.

(c) At the upper ends (say the upper third) of in-
lets of the pond or lake and their branches, more so when rela-
(4)
tively wind shaded or in the absence of sufficiently severe wave
action.

(d) Frequently in shallow waters not affected by
marked fluctuation of water or wave strong action, in the absence of
small mosquito destorying fish - often more so when certain
algae are present.

(5) When the production of Anopheles quadrimaculatus is
prolific over a considerable sized breeding area, such as in
an impounded water project containing such floatage, overgrown
banks with vegetation, hanging over into the water, collections
of aquatic plants, an absence of mosquito destroying minnows, etc.
then the adult mosquitoes of this kind emerging therefrom may be
found at residences and stables a mile distant from such a breed-
ing area. Under conditions similar to that outlined they have
not yet been found to travel to building 1 1/4 or 1 1/2 miles or more
distant from their source. In the investigation of this subject
it was generally found that where the production of adult
Anopheles quadrimaculatus was less prolific the adults were ab-
sent from houses about half a mile or more distant from the production
area.
PROPOSED REGULATIONS

In order that the impound ing of waters in the State of
________________ shall not render unhealthful a strip of land
about a mile wide adjacent to the maximum water elevation con-
tour line of the lake, and be instrumental in increasing the
prevalence of malaria in a considerable territory adjacent
thereto - - - - -

The following Rules and Regulations relating to measures
required to prevent the production of disease bearing mosquitoes
and malaria transmission for the Protection of Public Health
of the State of ______________________ etc. _______________.

1a In the State of ______________, whenever any pond
or lake or impounding of water or similar project is to be or
has been, located, (under the provisions of this act?), in any
county or part of the state where malaria exists or where there
is reasonable cause in the opinion of the State Board of Health
for fearing its introduction and dissemination, all or such parts of
the following general measures as the State Board of Health
deems essential are required to be accomplished and enforced
by the licensee, whenever so directed by the State Board of
Health for the protection of the public health.

2a In the area to be occupied by the reservoir, its
branches, bights and indentations, all brush, trees, undergrowth,
logs, stumps and similar objects, which if not removed would
float on the surface of the impounded water soon after the im-
(6)
pounding of water, and all of the above that if lying on the
ground or remaining in original or new position would probably
cause collections of floatage to gather, and thus constitute
conditions favorable to the protection of larvae of mosquitoes
capable of conveying malaria, shall be removed, burned or other-
wise satisfactorily disposed of, prior to the impounding of water.
The above does not include grass, vegetation, brush, trees,
stumps, etc and things that will not float or which will be perman-
ently and completely submerged at time of low water and which
isare therefore not of sanitary importance. In cutting brush and
trees, it is adviable to cut so that the remaining part will
be submerged, at least so far as practical one foot below minimum
water level to prevent future cost of removing floatage rafts,
etc. that might otherwise collect and become anchored.

3a The shore line of the reservoir, its branches, bights,
and indentations shall be cleared of brush, trees, undergrowth,
and the like, so as to prevent so far as practical, within
reasonable economic limits, the collection of drift and float-
age along shore. Also on gently sloping banks brush and saplings
shall be removed back from the high water line for about 25
feet horizontally, where its presence would prevent the strand-
ing of heavy or accumulated floatage during storms and at time
of high wind and water.

Pine trees shall be ringed where sufficiently close to
(7)
the water to cause the falling pine tags to collect in the
water of branches, bights, and indentations. Collections of
pine tag floatage frequently become prolific sources of Anopheles
larvae -- This deadening of pine trees shall be accomplished at
the time the projected construction of the dam is started.

4a Where advisable and practical the lake should be stock-
ed with (Gambusia affinis) sufficiently for affective mosquito
control, in accordance with definite written directions of the
State Board of Health.

Newly created lakes and ponds shall not be artificially
stocked with game fish without a written permit from the State
Board of Health.

5a During the first four years of the life of the new lake
the State Board of Health shall make such inspections of the
lake as are deemed essential, and any conditions found on the
impounded water project that are or may be detrimental to public
health or apt to cause an increase of malaria shall be modified
by the licensee so as to become satisfactory to the State Board
of Health. Prompt and proper care shall be taken to prevent
the growth of cattails, bullrushes and other aquatic or semi-
aquatic vegetation that offers protection for mosquito larvae
from their fish enemies.

It is understood that during the mosquito breeding season
that the licensee shall be held responsible for the prompt re-
moval of all dangerous floatage and floating debris in
(8)
bights, indentations and branch arms of the lake, which are
found to harbour mosquito larvae, and the licensee is required
to take all reasonable precautions to remove promptly, before
they become extensive, aquatic growths that multiply rapidly
and which are later expensive and difficult to remove.

6a Where practical and not unreasonably expensive to
accomplish, it is advisable to hold the water at higher level
from (November to June first) than during the mosquito season -
at least for the first three or four years. A greater portion
of the floatage will then be left stranded on the shore during
heavy winter storms and high flood and windy periods.

In case the water level is kept at a generally lower level
(say 2 to 3 feet) from June first to about October thirtieth,
it will cause the water edge to be against a clean bank, mostly
free of vegetation, and mosquito production will be markedly
reduced if not eliminated. Also the amount of maintenance
work necessary under such conditions to prevent mosquito pro-
duction would probably be small or negligible.

7a So far as practical all depressions that will be cover-
ed by water at flood stages and retain it at lower river stages
thus forming separate pools, shall be connected by ditch with
the lake so as to enable fish to enter at all times. Such
places are few in number but important in mosquito production.

8a The licensee shall be required to use every reason-
able precaution (in accordance with these regulations?) to
prevent the introduction or dissemination of malaria or other
(9)
communicable disease into the project areas and the territory
contiguous thereto and to carry out all written instructions
pertaining thereto from the State Board of Health.
